Cela fait partie de la mission Quesst de la NASA, qui vise à rendre les vols supersoniques au-dessus des terres plus silencieux et plus acceptables pour les habitants.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Le 28 octobre 2025, le X-59 a volé pour la première fois. Le pilote Nils Larson a décollé de Palmdale, en Californie, et a volé pendant 67 minutes à 230 mph et à une altitude de 12 000 pieds. L’avion est resté en dessous de la vitesse du son lors de ce vol pour vérifier ses systèmes et sa sécurité. Après l’atterrissage au centre de recherche Armstrong de la NASA, l’avion est officiellement passé des tests au sol aux tests en vol.

**Impact** – Ce premier vol est important car le X-59 est le premier nouvel avion expérimental que la NASA fait voler depuis plus de 20 ans, axé sur la réduction du bruit des vols supersoniques. Sa conception unique, avec un moteur sur le dessus et un système de caméras à la place d’une fenêtre avant, aide à réduire les forts bangs soniques en des bruits doux. **Prochaine étape** – La NASA testera maintenant le X-59 à des vitesses plus élevées, jusqu’à environ 925 mph à 55 000 pieds. Plus tard, la NASA prévoit de faire voler l’avion au-dessus de différentes communautés aux États-Unis pour recueillir des données sur la manière dont les gens perçoivent ces bruits soniques atténués. articles.personality_title_es: El X-59 de la NASA completa su primer vuelo, avanzando hacia viajes supersónicos silenciosos
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – La NASA ha estado trabajando durante años para construir el X-59, un avión especial diseñado para volar más rápido que el sonido mientras produce mucho menos ruido que los jets supersónicos normales. Esto forma parte de la misión Quesst de la NASA, que busca hacer que los vuelos supersónicos sobre tierra sean más silenciosos y aceptables para las personas que viven debajo.

**Qué pasó** – El 28 de octubre de 2025, el X-59 voló por primera vez. El piloto Nils Larson despegó desde Palmdale, California, y voló durante 67 minutos a 230 mph y a 12,000 pies de altura. El avión se mantuvo por debajo de la velocidad del sonido en este vuelo para revisar sus sistemas y seguridad. Después de aterrizar en el Centro de Investigación Armstrong de la NASA, el avión pasó oficialmente de las pruebas en tierra a las pruebas de vuelo.

**Impacto** – Este primer vuelo es importante porque el X-59 es el primer avión experimental nuevo que la NASA ha volado en más de 20 años enfocado en hacer el vuelo supersónico más silencioso. Su diseño único, incluyendo un motor en la parte superior y un sistema especial de cámaras en lugar de una ventana frontal, ayuda a reducir los fuertes estampidos sónicos a golpes suaves. Si tiene éxito, esto podría cambiar la forma en que los aviones vuelan rápido sobre tierra sin molestar a las personas con ruido.

El equipo estudiará cómo la forma del avión afecta las ondas de choque y el ruido. Más adelante, la NASA planea volar el avión sobre diferentes comunidades en Estados Unidos para recopilar datos sobre cómo las personas escuchan y perciben estos golpes sónicos más suaves. Esta información ayudará a crear nuevas reglas para vuelos supersónicos silenciosos en el futuro.

articles.title: Mosquito proboscis repurposed as a fine nozzle for 3D printing
articles.summary: When engineers struggled to make 3D printer nozzles narrow enough for their needs, they turned to nature and found the proboscis of a female mosquito had exactly the properties they needed
articles.content:
When engineers struggled to make 3D printer nozzles narrow enough for their needs, they turned to nature and found the proboscis of a female mosquito had exactly the properties they needed

A mosquito proboscis adapted as a nozzle for a 3D printer Changhong Cao et al. 2025

A severed mosquito proboscis can be turned into an extremely fine nozzle for 3D printing, and this could help create replacement tissues and organs for transplants.

Changhong Cao at McGill University in Montreal, Canada, and his colleagues developed the technique, which they call 3D necroprinting, because they were unable to find nozzles thin enough for their work on manufacturing very fine structures. The narrowest commercially available nozzle they could find had an interior bore of 35 micrometres and also came with a hefty £60 ($80) price tag.

Advertisement

They experimented with techniques like glass-pulling, but found these nozzles also proved expensive and were very brittle.

“This made us think whether there is an alternative,” says Cao. “If Mother Nature can provide what we need with an affordable cost, why make it ourselves?”

The researchers tasked a graduate student, Justin Puma, with finding a natural organ that could handle the task, considering everything from scorpion stingers to snake fangs. They eventually found that a mosquito proboscis – in particular, the stiffer version found in female Egyptian mosquitoes (Aedes aegypti) – allowed them to print structures as thin as 20 micrometres.

Free newsletter Sign up to The Daily The latest on what’s new in science and why it matters each day. Sign up to newsletter

Cao says an experienced worker can make six nozzles an hour from mosquito mouthparts at a cost of less than a dollar each, making the process easy to scale up. The natural nozzles can be fitted to existing 3D printers and are relatively long-lasting considering their biological origin: after two weeks, around 30 per cent of them begin to fail, but they can be stored frozen for up to a year.

The team tested the technique using a bio-ink called Pluronic F-127, which can build scaffolds for biological tissues including blood vessels – a potential method for creating replacement organs.

There have been several other examples of parts from small creatures being used in machines, including a moth antenna used in a smell-seeking drone and dead spiders used as mechanical grippers.

Christian Griffiths at Swansea University, UK, says the work is another example of human engineers struggling to match the tools developed by nature.

“You’ve got a couple of million years of mosquito evolution: we’re trying to catch up with that,” he says. “I think that maybe they’ve got the advantage on us there.”
articles.reasoning: The article describes a novel bio-inspired technological breakthrough where mosquito proboscises are repurposed as ultra-fine nozzles for 3D printing, enabling the creation of very fine structures potentially useful for manufacturing replacement tissues and organs. This innovation offers a cost-effective, scalable, and practical solution with broad implications for biomedical engineering and healthcare, representing a meaningful advancement with real-world positive impact.
articles.personality_title: Mosquito mouthparts used to create ultra-fine 3D printer nozzles
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Engineers needed very thin nozzles for 3D printers to build tiny structures, but the thinnest ones available were expensive and fragile.

**What happened** – Researchers at McGill University found that the sharp mouthpart of female mosquitoes, called the proboscis, could be used as a natural nozzle for 3D printers. They cut off the proboscis and attached it to printers, allowing them to print details as small as 20 micrometres.

**Impact** – These mosquito nozzles cost less than a dollar each, much cheaper than commercial nozzles. They can be made quickly and fit on regular 3D printers. This method helps make very fine structures, like scaffolds for growing replacement body tissues and organs, which could improve medical treatments.

**What’s next step** – The team will likely continue testing this method with different materials and explore how to produce larger amounts of these natural nozzles for wider use in medicine and engineering.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Scientists turned mosquito mouthparts into tiny, affordable 3D printer nozzles that could help build replacement tissues and organs.

Ils ont coupé cette trompe et l’ont fixée aux imprimantes, ce qui leur a permis d’imprimer des détails aussi petits que 20 micromètres.

Elles peuvent être fabriquées rapidement et s’adaptent aux imprimantes 3D classiques. Cette méthode aide à créer des structures très fines, comme des échafaudages pour cultiver des tissus et organes de remplacement, ce qui pourrait améliorer les traitements médicaux.

articles.personality_presentation_es:
